results.title: Funny Games
results.brief_description: Two psychotic young men take a mother, father, and son hostage in their vacation cabin and force them to play sadistic “games” with one another for their own amusement.

constellations_other.name: Time to rewind (The Gardens Between)
constellations_other.description: This constellation explores media works that manipulate time, specifically by utitlising a reverse play structure to tell a story.

results.title: Funny Felix = Drole de felix [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Olivier Ducastel, Jacques Martineau, Phillipe Martinez, Les Films Pelleas and Peccadillo Pictures
results.brief_description: Felix (Sami Bouajila) is an Arab French man who, on finding himself unemployed at his job on the wharfs of Callais, decides to undertake a five day hitchhiking journey to find his estranged father in Marseilles. Organizing for his boyfriend to meet him at the end of the week, Felix takes up his backpack and begins a road trip which becomes an investigation of not only contemporary France, but also a deeply human exploration of the meaning of family. Whilst he confronts bigotry and violence on the way, he also engages in fleeting but emotionally rich encounters with women and men who become a surrogate brother, grandmother, cousin, sister and father for him. ‘Funny Felix’ is one of the best examples of the new humanist French cinema that has developed in the late 1990s. Though acknowledging the social divisions and fissures of contemporary Europe, films such as ‘Funny Felix’ are committed to celebrating and detailing the diverse experiences of modern working class lives. In contrast to English-language gay themes films, “Funny Felix” is free of moralism and segregated identities. Felix, whose positive HIV-status is treated with compassion, but also with blithe acceptance, is expertly played by Bouajila. The cast includes Ariane Ascardie and Patachou. In French with with English subtitles.

results.title: Funny face
results.creator_credit: Stanley Donen, Roger Edens and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Fred Astaire stars as a fashion photographer looking for a new face to promote Kay Thompson’s fashion magazine. He discovers Audrey Hepburn working in a bookstore and transforms her into a model on the cover of the “Vogue-like” magazine. Shot on location in Paris and featuring songs by George and Ira Gershwin, “Funny face” is a song and dance delight, with romantic backdrops. Hepburn in her Givency clothes is stunning.

results.title: Funny by George
results.creator_credit: Don Percy, Jeremy Kewley and Onkus Pictures
results.brief_description: A documentary about the life of one of Australia’s most famous and influential comedians. Wallace was a creative force as a writer of his own material for vaudeville sketches and feature films and as a painter, musician, dancer and composer. From his early beginnings in country travelling shows and vaudeville, he became Australia’s first genuine box office star of the sound era appearing in five feature films and achieving international success. Using rare photographs, home movies, feature film footage and contemporary interviews, the filmmakers explore his personal and professional life and examine his lasting influence, thus restoring Wallace to his rightful place as a key figure in Australian entertainment history. Narrated by Bill Kerr.

results.title: Funny Business
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Funny Business
results.brief_description: Funny Business is a documentary-style television series about the craft of comedy consisting of six 50-minute episodes.

constellations_other.name: Sounds unreal
constellations_other.description: A history of syncing sound effects, a craft known as Foley in the USA and bootstepping in the UK.

results.description:
Funny Business is a documentary style television series about the craft of comedy consisting of six 50-minute episodes. The first episode aired in the UK 22 November 1992. The show was also shown in Germany and released on video. It was directed by David Hinton. The writers were Rowan Atkinson, Robin Driscoll, and David Hinton. It was produced by Tiger Television Productions.

The show featured appearances by many comedians, including Rowan Atkinson who made an appearance both as the presenter/narrator, and as an aspiring comedy actor named Kevin. Atkinson demonstrated many of the principles of comedy in a manner which was instantly identifiable to anyone familiar with his Mr. Bean character.
description_for_label:

results.title: Funny business
results.creator_credit: David Hinton, Sarah Williams and Tiger Television
results.brief_description: Rowan Atkinson knows his rubber face and gangly limbs are his tools of trade. The exaggerated gestures, tortured twitch of an eyebrow or deadpan expression guaranteed the phenomenal success of “Not the Nine O’Clock News”, “Black Adder” and “Mr. Bean”. There is however an art to being funny, and as mime artist Kevin Bartholomew (dressed in a lime green skin-tight body suit) the amazing rubber-faced one shows us, along with fellow comedy masters including John Cleese and Peter Sellers, that there is comedy potential in every part of the human anatomy.

results.title: Funny bones
results.creator_credit: Peter Chelsom, Simon Fields and Hollywood Pictures
results.brief_description: Tommy Fawkes (Oliver Platt), is a struggling stand-up comedian trying to live up to the legacy that his famous father George Fawkes (Jerry Lewis) has created. George is now retired, and Tommy is struggling to get his career started. After yet another painful failure onstage, Tommy decides to travel back to Blackpool, England, where his family’s history and comedy originated and during his stay, Tommy discovers some not so funny secrets about his family and his past. During this time he develops a peculiar friendship with the mysterious Jack Parker (Lee Evans), the seemingly dim, comedian-savant. This film, a “black slapstick comedy” goes beyond any genre, utilizing brilliant psychological and physical performances right down to the eyebrow raising cameo from Oliver Reed. Written by Peter Chelsom and Peter Flannery.

results.title: Fungus plants
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and ERPI Classroom Films
results.brief_description: Emphasis is given to the various mushrooms whose growth and reproduction are illustrated by time-lapse photography and animation. Moulds and other fungi are also presented by these same techniques. Their economic importance is indicated.

results.title: Fungi and man
results.brief_description: Shows how fungi can alter the physical and chemical structure of organic materials in the environment, including humans themselves, in ways both chemical and harmful. Provides clear photography of fungi physiology.
